Recommended general use; balances security and performance

General purpose; faster than RSA signing; larger signatures
Recommended general use; most balanced security/performance
Highest security; suitable for long-term archival
Alternate lattice signature (Falcon-512); tiny signature (~0.65KB) and fast verification (requires floating-point arithmetic)
High-security Falcon variant; small signature (~1.25KB) and fast verification
Conservative hash-based; slow signing but small keys
SHAKE-based hash-based signature; NIST recommends SHAKE variants for long-term security; conservative choice with tiny keys (32B pub)
Fast signing variant (~5x faster than 128s); trades larger signatures (~17KB) for signing speed; good for high-throughput scenarios
SHAKE-based fast signing at Level 1; ~17KB signatures but significantly faster signing than 128s; preferred over SHA2 for long-term use
Level 3 hash-based with small signatures (~16KB); very slow signing but minimal key sizes; suited for firmware signing and archival
SHAKE-based Level 3 small signature variant; NIST-preferred hash function for longevity; ~16KB signatures with tiny 48B public key
Level 3 fast signing variant; ~36KB signatures but ~5x faster signing than 192s; useful when signing throughput matters more than bandwidth
SHAKE-based Level 3 fast variant; ~36KB signatures with fast signing; NIST-preferred hash for long-term quantum resilience
Highest security hash-based (Level 5); ~30KB signatures; extremely slow signing but maximum quantum resilience for archival use
SHAKE-based Level 5 with smallest signatures at this security level (~30KB); NIST-preferred for maximum long-term quantum resistance
256-bit fast signing; ~50KB signatures
SHAKE-based Level 5 fast variant; ~50KB signatures but ~5x faster signing than 256s; NIST-preferred hash for top-tier security

Stateful hash-based (eXtended Merkle Signature Scheme). Same state management constraints as LMS. Limited number of signatures per key.
